div1.p: Frost discusses Carter's upcoming lectures on malaria and yellow fever, at Johns Hopkins.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
SCHOOL OF HYGIENE AND PUBLIC HEALTH
310-312 WEST MONUMENT STREET
BALTIMORE, M D. February 20, 1922.
DEPARTMENT OF EPIDEMIOLOGY
Dr. H. R. Carter,
2121 California Street, N.W.,
Washington, D.C.
My dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
We are indeed deeply indebted to you for your
willingness to give the three lectures on malaria and
yellow fever, and we will all look forward to them with
the greatest pleasure.

The dates which you suggest, Tuesday, March
7th, Thursday, March 9th and Tuesday, March 14th, will
be entirely satisfactory, and as these days are allotted
to my time in epidemiology I can readily give you what-
ever hour best suits your convenience.

Following your suggestion I will provisionally
schedule your lectures for 11:30 A.M. on the 7th and
14th and 2:30 P.M. on the 9th. I can, however, arrange
to give you a morning hour (11:30) on Thursday, March
9th as well as on Tuesdays, if this would suit you better.
If you will let me know a few days in advance just what
hours you prefer they can be arranged in accordance with
your convenience.

As to the scope of your lectures I think that
it may best be left entirely to you to include whatever
you think of most importance for a group of students
most of whom may expect to have to deal with malaria and
possibly yellow fever in the capacity of health officers
or field investigators.

If you are not in a hurry to get back to Washing-
ton will you have lunch with me on the day of your first
lecture, and I hope on the other days as well?

With sincere regards and most cordial apprecia-
tion of your kindness in giving the lectures, I am,
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, W. H. Frost. WHF:G
